chapters.title: Indexes
chapters.description: In this chapter you will understand indexes their importance and how they are useful in real world application or day to day trading.

blocks.text:
Imagine someone asks you:
“What’s the traffic situation in your city right now?”

Your city has thousands of roads, but you won’t check each road one by one.
Instead, you’ll look at a few important roads and junctions in different areas.

If most of them are crowded → traffic is bad

If most are smooth → traffic is normal

Those few important roads act as a summary or indicator of the entire city’s traffic.

Same logic applies to the stock market

Now think about the stock market:

There are ~5,000 companies on BSE

~2,000 companies on NSE

Checking every stock to know how the market is doing is impractical.

So instead:

We pick a few important companies

These companies belong to key industries

We observe how most of them are moving

👉 If most are rising → market is up
👉 If most are falling → market is down
👉 If mixed → market is sideways/flat

What is an Index then?

An Index is:

A collection of selected important stocks

That represents the overall market

Just like key roads represent city traffic

Whenever someone asks:

“How is the market today?”

You don’t look at every stock —
You simply check the index.

✅ These selected stocks together form the stock market index.

In one line

An index is a benchmark that tells you how the overall market is performing by tracking a few representative stocks.

You do not need to track individual companies one by one to understand how the stock market is performing.
Instead, a selected group of important companies is continuously monitored to give a quick and accurate sense of overall market movement.

This pre-packaged indicator of market sentiment is called a Stock Market Index.

An index acts like a summary of the market, helping investors understand whether the market is generally moving up, down, or sideways.

Important Indices in India

India has several widely tracked stock market indices:

Sensex
Represents the Bombay Stock Exchange (BSE). It consists of 30 large, well-established companies.

Nifty 50
Represents the National Stock Exchange (NSE). It consists of 50 actively traded and influential companies.

Bank Nifty
Represents the banking sector as a whole. It tracks major banking stocks listed on the NSE.

Each of these indices reflects the performance of a specific segment of the market.

Why “S&P” Sensex?

S&P stands for Standard & Poor’s, a global credit rating and financial analytics company.

S&P provides the technical expertise required to construct and maintain stock market indices.

This methodology is licensed to the BSE, which is why the index is called S&P BSE Sensex.

For the NSE:

Indices are maintained by a separate entity called NSE Indices Limited.

What Does Nifty 50 Represent?

Nifty 50 includes the most frequently traded and liquid stocks on the NSE.

These companies come from different sectors of the economy.

Together, they provide a reliable and updated representation of the overall market.

An ideal index:

Reflects market movements accurately

Is regularly updated

Represents the broader economy, not just one company or sector

In short

A stock market index is a carefully selected group of stocks that helps you understand how the overall market or a specific sector is performing—without tracking every individual company.

Practical Uses of a Stock Market Index

Some of the practical uses of a stock market index are discussed in this section.

A stock market index reflects the overall sentiment and trend of the market. It broadly represents the state of the country’s economy.

When the index is rising, it indicates that market participants are optimistic about the future.

When the index is falling, it suggests pessimism about future economic prospects.

Understanding Market Sentiment Using an Index

For example, the Nifty 50 value on 21st November 2022 was 18,150.
Around six months earlier, the Nifty 50 was at 15,820.

This means:

The index moved up by 2,300 points

A rise of approximately 14.75% in six months

Such a sharp upward movement indicates bullish sentiment in the market.
In other words, market participants were optimistic about the Indian economic future during this period.

Index Movement Across Different Time Frames

The time frame used to observe index movement can vary depending on the analysis.

For instance:

At 9:30 AM on 21st November, the index was at 18,140

One hour later, it dropped to 18,099

This represents a fall of nearly 40 points within an hour.

Such short-term movement indicates that:

Market participants were not enthusiastic in the short term

Short-term sentiment can differ from long-term sentiment

Key Takeaway

A stock market index helps assess both long-term and short-term market sentiment

Long-term trends reflect economic outlook

Short-term movements reflect immediate reactions of market participants

This makes the index a powerful tool to understand how the market is feeling at any given point in time.

A yardstick is required to measure performance for any trading or investing activity.

Assume that over the last year:

You invested Rs. 100,000

You generated a return of Rs. 20,000

Your total corpus became Rs. 120,000

At first glance, a 20% return appears impressive.

However, consider this:

What if the Nifty Index gained 30% during the same year?

In such a case, even though you made money, you actually underperformed the market.

Role of the Index in Performance Evaluation

The primary objective of most market participants is to outperform the index, not just generate positive returns.

Without an index:

You cannot objectively judge how well you performed

Returns lack context

Performance comparison becomes meaningless

The index provides a standard benchmark against which:

Trading performance

Investment returns

Portfolio efficiency

can be evaluated accurately.

Key Takeaway

Absolute returns alone do not indicate good performance

Returns must always be compared against a relevant market index

The index helps determine whether you have outperformed or underperformed the market.

Trading on the index is one of the most popular uses of a stock market index.

A majority of traders prefer trading the index rather than individual stocks. This is because index trading allows traders to take a broader view of the economy or overall market conditions and convert that view into a trade.

Index traders usually take short-term positions, aiming to benefit from near-term movements in the overall market rather than company-specific events.

Illustrative Example

Consider the following situation:

At 10:30 AM, the Finance Minister is scheduled to deliver the annual budget speech.
An hour before the announcement, the Nifty index is trading at 18,150 points.

You expect the budget to be favorable for the country’s economy.

What do you think will happen to the index?

If the budget is perceived as positive, the index is likely to move upward, as it reflects the performance and expectations of the broader economy.

To express this view, you may choose to buy the index at 18,150.

Outcome of the Trade

As expected, the budget announcement is positive.
The index rises to 18,450 points.

You can now:

Book your profits

Exit the trade with a 300-point gain

How Is Index Trading Possible?

Trading on the index is made possible through the derivatives segment of the stock market.

While derivatives will be covered in detail later, it is important to understand at this stage that:

Direct buying or selling of an index is not possible

Index exposure is achieved through derivative instruments

Key Takeaway

Index trading allows traders to take a view on the overall market or economy

It is commonly used for short-term trading

Such trades are executed through the derivatives market

Investors typically build a diversified portfolio of stocks.
A standard equity portfolio often consists of 15 to 20 stocks, usually held with a long-term investment horizon.

Even though these stocks are selected for long-term growth, investors may anticipate periods of prolonged market decline. Historical events such as the 2008 financial crisis demonstrate how broad market downturns can significantly erode portfolio value, even if the underlying companies remain fundamentally strong.

In such situations, investors can use the stock market index as a hedging tool.

What Is Portfolio Hedging?

Portfolio hedging refers to the practice of reducing or offsetting potential losses in an investment portfolio by taking an opposing position elsewhere.

Since most diversified portfolios tend to move in line with the broader market:

A market-wide fall can negatively impact the portfolio

Even strong individual stocks may decline during market stress

By taking a position on the index, investors can protect their portfolio from large downside risks during adverse market conditions.

Role of the Index in Hedging

The index represents the overall market movement.
If an investor expects a broad market decline, they can use index-based instruments to hedge their portfolio exposure.

Index Construction Methodology

Understanding how a stock market index is constructed is important, especially for participants who intend to trade or analyze the index in depth.

As discussed earlier, an index is a collection of selected stocks drawn from different sectors of the economy. These stocks together represent the overall state and movement of the economy.

Stock Selection Criteria

To be included in an index, a stock must satisfy certain predefined criteria. These criteria typically relate to:

Market capitalization

Liquidity

Trading frequency

Sector representation

Once a stock qualifies and becomes part of the index, it must continue to meet these criteria.
If a stock fails to maintain the required standards, it is removed and replaced by another eligible stock.

This ensures that the index remains relevant, representative, and efficient over time.

Weightage of Stocks in an Index

After the eligible stocks are selected, each stock is assigned a specific weight within the index.

Weightage determines:

How much influence a stock has on index movement

The extent to which price changes in that stock affect the index

For example, if a stock has a weight of 3.85% in the index, it means approximately 3.85% of the index’s movement can be attributed to that stock’s price movement.

How Are Weights Assigned?

There are multiple ways to assign weights, but Indian stock exchanges follow the free-float market capitalization method.

Under this method:

Stocks with a larger free-float market capitalization receive higher weight

Stocks with smaller free-float market capitalization receive lower weight

This approach ensures that companies with greater market participation have a proportionally higher impact on the index.

Free-Float Market Capitalization

Free-float market capitalization is calculated as:

Number of shares available for public trading × Market price per share

Only shares that are freely available for trading are considered. Promoter-held shares and restricted shares are excluded.

Example:
If a company has:

100 shares available in the market

Share price of ₹50

Then, free-float market capitalization =
100 × 50 = ₹5,000

Impact of Heavyweight Stocks

Stocks with the highest weight in the index are called index heavyweights.

Movements in these stocks have a significant impact on the index level.
As a result, the index tends to be more sensitive to price changes in heavyweight stocks compared to lower-weight stocks.

Key Takeaways

An index is constructed using a defined stock selection process

Each stock is assigned a weight based on free-float market capitalization

Higher market capitalization leads to higher index weight

Heavyweight stocks influence index movement the most

Sector-Specific Indices

While broad market indices such as the Sensex and Nifty represent the overall stock market, there are indices that track the performance of specific sectors of the economy. These are known as sectoral indices.

Sectoral indices help investors and traders understand how a particular industry or sector is performing, independent of the broader market.

Examples of Sectoral Indices

Bank Nifty (NSE)
Represents the performance and sentiment of the banking sector. It includes major public and private sector banks listed on the NSE.

CNX IT (NSE)
Represents the performance of the information technology sector and reflects the collective movement of IT stocks in the market.

Both the BSE and NSE maintain multiple sector-specific indices covering industries such as banking, IT, FMCG, metals, pharmaceuticals, energy, and infrastructure.

Purpose of Sectoral Indices

Sectoral indices are useful for:

Tracking sector-specific trends and cycles

Comparing performance across different industries

Making sector rotation decisions

Trading or investing based on industry-level outlooks

Construction and Maintenance

The construction and maintenance of sectoral indices follow the same principles as broader market indices:

Stock selection based on predefined eligibility criteria

Weight assignment using free-float market capitalization

Periodic review and rebalancing

This ensures that sectoral indices remain representative of the sectors they track.

Key Takeaway

Broad indices reflect the overall market

Sectoral indices reflect the performance of individual industries

They provide deeper insight into sector-specific opportunities and risks

Market Index

Fortunately, you do not need to track individual companies to understand how the overall stock market is performing. A selected group of important companies is pre-chosen and continuously monitored to provide a snapshot of the broader market’s performance.

These pre-selected stocks, when taken together, are referred to as the Market Index.

Major Market Indices in India

There are two primary stock market indices in India:

S&P BSE Sensex – Represents the Bombay Stock Exchange (BSE)

Nifty 50 – Represents the National Stock Exchange (NSE)

Both indices are professionally constructed, maintained, and regularly monitored to reflect market sentiment accurately.

About the S&P BSE Sensex

S&P stands for Standard & Poor’s, a global credit rating agency.
S&P provides the technical expertise required to construct the index, which has been licensed to the Bombay Stock Exchange. This is why the index carries the S&P prefix.

About the Nifty 50

The Nifty 50 consists of the largest and most actively traded stocks listed on the National Stock Exchange. These stocks are selected based on liquidity, market capitalization, and representation across key sectors of the economy.

The Nifty 50 is maintained by India Index Services & Products Limited (IISL), a subsidiary of the NSE.

Key Takeaway

Market indices provide a quick and reliable measure of overall market performance

Sensex represents the BSE, while Nifty 50 represents the NSE

Indices eliminate the need to track individual stocks to understand market direction.

Benchmarking Performance Using the Index

For any trading or investing activity, a benchmark is required to evaluate performance objectively. Consider the following example.

Assume that over the last one year, you invested Rs.100,000 and generated a return of Rs.20,000, resulting in a total corpus of Rs.120,000. On the surface, a 20% return appears to be a strong performance.

However, suppose during the same period the Nifty index moved from 10,000 to 13,000, delivering a return of 30%.

Understanding Relative Performance

In this situation, although your investment generated positive returns, it becomes evident that your portfolio underperformed the broader market.

Without referencing the market index, it would be difficult to determine whether your performance was good or poor. The index provides the necessary context to evaluate results accurately.

Role of the Index as a Benchmark

The index serves as a benchmark to measure the performance of traders and investors. It allows participants to compare their returns against the broader market.

In most cases, the objective of a market participant is not merely to generate profits, but to outperform the index.

Key Takeaway

Absolute returns alone do not indicate true performance

The index provides a standardized benchmark

Performance should always be evaluated relative to the market.

Index Weighting Methodology

There are several ways to assign weights to the stocks that make up an index. However, Indian stock exchanges follow a methodology known as free-float market capitalization.

Under this method, the weight assigned to a stock in the index depends on its free-float market capitalization. A company with a higher free-float market capitalization carries a higher weight in the index.

Free-Float Market Capitalization

Free-float market capitalization is calculated as the product of the total number of shares available for trading in the market and the current market price of the stock.

In simpler terms, it reflects the market value of shares that are actively traded and excludes shares held by promoters or other long-term holders that are not readily available in the market.

Illustrative Example

Consider a company, ABC, with 100 shares outstanding in the market. If the stock price is ₹50, the free-float market capitalization of the company would be:

100 × 50 = ₹5,000

This value is used to determine the stock’s weight in the index relative to other constituent stocks.

Sector-Specific Indices

While indices such as the Sensex and Nifty represent the broader market, certain indices are designed to track the performance of specific sectors. These are referred to as sector-specific indices.

For example, the Bank Nifty index on the National Stock Exchange represents the performance of stocks belonging to the banking industry. It reflects the overall sentiment and movement specific to the banking sector.

Similarly, the IT Index on the National Stock Exchange represents the performance of Information Technology companies listed on the exchange. It captures the collective behavior of IT stocks in the market.

Construction of Sectoral Indices

Both the Bombay Stock Exchange (BSE) and the National Stock Exchange (NSE) maintain multiple sector-specific indices. The methodology used to construct and maintain these indices is similar to that of the broader market indices.

Stocks are selected based on predefined criteria, assigned appropriate weights, and reviewed periodically to ensure accurate representation of the sector.

Important Note

It is important to note that not all sector-specific indices are tradable in the same manner as broad indices like the Nifty 50. Some sectoral indices are meant primarily for analysis and benchmarking rather than active trading.

blocks.text:
Jargons

This chapter is intended to introduce you to some of the most commonly used terms in the stock market along with their meanings and practical context.

Bull Market (Bullish) – When you expect stock prices to rise, you are said to be bullish on the stock. From a broader market viewpoint, if the stock market index shows a sustained upward movement over a period of time, the market is described as being in a bull phase.
Example – The stock market remained bullish from mid-2020 until early 2022.

Bear Market (Bearish) – When you anticipate stock prices to fall, you are considered bearish on the stock. At the market level, if the stock market index declines over a prolonged period, it is referred to as a bear market.
Example – The market experienced a bearish phase from early 2008 to late 2009.

Trend – The term “trend” generally indicates the overall direction in which the market is moving along with its momentum. For instance, if the market is falling sharply, the prevailing trend is described as bearish. If prices are moving within a narrow range without a clear direction, the trend is said to be sideways.

Face value of a stock – The face value (FV), also known as par value, represents the nominal value of a share. Face value is mainly relevant from a corporate actions point of view. Corporate actions will be discussed in a separate chapter.

Generally, when companies announce dividends, stock splits, or bonus issues, these actions are structured with reference to the face value of the share.

For example, the face value of Infosys is ₹5. If the company declares an annual dividend of ₹63 per share, this translates to a dividend of 1260%, calculated as 63 divided by 5.

In short, face value does not indicate the market price of a stock, but it plays an important role in understanding dividends and other corporate announcements.

The 52-week high is the highest price at which a stock has traded during the past 52 weeks, which roughly corresponds to one full calendar year.
Similarly, the 52-week low represents the lowest price at which the stock has traded during the same 52-week period.

The 52-week high and low help in understanding the price range within which a stock has moved over the last year. Many traders believe that when a stock approaches or breaks its 52-week high, it may signal a bullish trend in the near future. In the same way, when a stock touches its 52-week low, some traders interpret it as a sign of a bearish trend going forward.

All-time high / low

The all-time high is similar in concept to the 52-week high, except that it refers to the highest price the stock has ever traded at since it was first listed on the exchange.
Likewise, the all-time low is the lowest price at which the stock has ever traded since its listing.

These levels give a long-term historical perspective of a stock’s price behavior and are often used by investors and traders to assess long-term strength or weakness.

The stock exchange defines a price range within which a stock is allowed to trade on a particular trading day. This range is known as the upper and lower circuit.

The upper circuit limit is the maximum price a stock can reach during the day, while the lower circuit limit is the minimum price it can fall to. These limits are generally set at 2%, 5%, 10%, or 20%, depending on the stock and the exchange’s predefined criteria.

Circuit limits are imposed to prevent excessive price fluctuations, especially when a stock reacts sharply to company-specific news or events. By restricting extreme price movements, the exchange aims to maintain orderly trading and protect market participants from sudden volatility.

The rules and limits related to circuits can differ for derivative stocks and indices, and these variations will be discussed in detail at a later stage.

A long position, or going long, refers to the direction of a trade where you expect the price of an asset to rise.

For example, if you have already bought, or plan to buy, shares of Biocon, you are said to be long on Biocon. Similarly, if you buy the Nifty index with the expectation that it will move higher, you are holding a long position on Nifty.

In simple terms, taking a long position means you are anticipating an upward movement in the price. When a trader or investor holds a long position in a stock or an index, they are considered bullish on that asset.

A short position, or going short, refers to a type of transaction where an asset is sold first with the intention of buying it back later at a lower price. This concept can feel a bit counter-intuitive at first, so let’s understand it with a simple real-life example.

Around mid-2014, Xiaomi entered the Indian market through an exclusive partnership with Flipkart to sell its flagship smartphone, the Mi3. The expected price of the phone was around ₹14,000. To purchase the Mi3, users had to be registered on Flipkart, and the registration window was open only for a limited time.

I registered promptly, but my colleague Rajesh did not. Even though he wanted the phone, he couldn’t buy it due to missing the registration deadline.

Out of desperation, Rajesh approached me with an offer. He said he would buy the phone from me for ₹16,500 and asked me to sell it to him immediately. I agreed, even though I didn’t yet own the phone, and Rajesh paid me the money upfront.

At that point, I had effectively sold a phone that I did not own. However, I knew I could still purchase it later from Flipkart and deliver it to Rajesh. The risk in this situation was simple—if the phone’s actual price turned out to be higher than ₹16,500, I would incur a loss. For instance, if the price had been ₹18,000, the loss would have been ₹1,500 (18,000 − 16,500).

As it turned out, the phone was priced at ₹14,000 as expected. I bought it from Flipkart, delivered it to Rajesh, and made a profit of ₹2,500 (16,500 − 14,000).

If you look closely at the sequence of events, I sold the product first and bought it later. This “sell first, buy later” approach is exactly what defines a short trade.

The idea of short selling often feels counter-intuitive because, in everyday life, we are not used to selling something we do not own—unless we think like a trader.

Let us return to the stock market with a simple example.

On day 1, you buy Wipro shares at ₹405. Two days later (day 3), the stock price rises to ₹425, and you sell your shares. In this case, you make a profit of ₹20 per share.

Here,

First leg of the trade: Buy Wipro at ₹405

Second leg of the trade: Sell Wipro at ₹425

Your view was bullish, and the profit came from a rise in price.

Now consider a different situation.

On day 4, Wipro is trading at ₹425, but you are bearish and believe the stock will fall back to ₹405. Can you still make a profit? Yes—by short selling.

You sell Wipro at ₹425, and after two days, when the stock falls to ₹405, you buy it back.

In this case:

First leg of the trade: Sell at ₹425

Second leg of the trade: Buy back at ₹405

This is how short selling works—you sell first at a higher price and buy later at a lower price.

Effectively, this is the same trade as buying at ₹405 and selling at ₹425, but executed in reverse order.

A common question arises here:
How can you sell Wipro shares without owning them?

Just like the earlier example where a phone was sold before owning it, the stock market allows short selling under certain rules.

An important point to remember is that when you short a stock in the cash segment, you must buy it back on the same day before the market closes. This means short selling in the cash market is strictly an intraday activity.

In the derivatives segment, however, short positions can be carried forward for multiple days. For now, ignore derivatives and focus on the fact that all cash market short positions must be squared off before market close.

Key Takeaways

When you short a stock, you have a bearish view.

You profit if the stock price falls.

You incur a loss if the stock price rises.

In the cash market, short selling requires you to buy back the stock on the same day, unless you are using derivatives.

Shorting a stock is simple in execution—you select the stock and place a sell order—but it requires clear understanding and discipline.

Square off is a term used to indicate that you are closing an existing trading position.

If you hold a long position in a stock, squaring off means selling the stock. When you sell to close a long position, it is not considered short selling—you are simply exiting an already open long trade.

In the same way, if you are short on a stock, squaring off means buying the stock back. When you repurchase the stock, you are only closing your short position; this action does not mean you are taking a long position.

In simple terms, squaring off always refers to closing an existing position, regardless of whether the position is long or short.

Summary:

When you are long, square off by selling the stock

When you are short, square off by buying the stock

Intraday Position

An intraday position is a trade that is opened with the intention of being squared off on the same trading day.

Such positions cannot be carried forward to the next day. For example, all short positions in stocks (cash segment) are intraday positions and must be closed before the market closes.

Intraday trading focuses on short-term price movements within a single trading session, and positions are automatically squared off by the broker if they are not closed manually.

OHLC in stock prices stands for Open, High, Low, and Close. These four values describe the complete price movement of a stock for a single trading day.

Open is the price at which the stock begins trading for the day.

High is the highest price the stock reaches during the trading session.

Low is the lowest price at which the stock trades during the day.

Close is the final trading price of the stock when the market closes.

These values are widely used in price charts and technical analysis to understand intraday price behavior. The detailed interpretation of OHLC will be covered later in the technical analysis module.

Example:
If the OHLC values of ACC on 17th June were 1486, 1511, 1467, and 1499, then:

Open = 1486

High = 1511

Low = 1467

Close = 1499

Volume refers to the total number of shares traded in a stock during a specific trading day. It includes both buy and sell transactions combined.

Volume plays an important role in understanding market activity and price movement. A higher volume generally indicates greater participation and interest in a stock, while lower volume suggests reduced trading activity. The relationship between volume and price will be discussed in more detail in the technical analysis module.

Example:
On 17th June, if the trading volume of ACC was 5,33,819 shares, it means that a total of 5,33,819 shares of ACC were bought and sold during that trading session.

A market segment refers to a specific division of the stock exchange where a particular category of financial instruments is traded. Each type of instrument differs in terms of risk, return, and trading characteristics. Broadly, the exchange functions through multiple market segments.

1. Capital Market (CM)

The capital market segment deals with tradable securities such as equity shares and exchange-traded funds (ETFs). Whenever you buy or sell shares of a company, the transaction takes place in the capital market segment.
Short selling of stocks is also permitted in this segment. The capital market is often referred to as the cash market or spot market.

2. Futures and Options (FO)

The Futures and Options segment, commonly known as the equity derivatives segment, is where leveraged instruments are traded. This segment allows traders to take positions using futures and options contracts.
The derivatives market will be covered in detail in the Futures and Options module.

3. Currency Derivatives Segment (CDS)

The currency derivatives segment facilitates trading in currency pairs such as USD/INR, EUR/INR, and JPY/INR. Trading in this segment is conducted through futures and options contracts, which is why it is classified as a currency derivative market.

4. Wholesale Debt Market (WDM)

The wholesale debt market focuses on fixed-income securities, including government bonds, treasury bills, and corporate debt instruments. This segment is primarily used by institutional participants rather than retail traders.
